title: Minnesota teen gets life, parole chance in execution...
text:
Deshon I. Bonnell, 19, was found guilty of killing Joshua Lavalley, of Aurora, on January 6, 2019, execution-style in the woods of northeastern Minnesota. He was sentenced to 30 years in jail

A teenager accused of killing a man execution-style in the woods of northeastern Minnesota has been sentenced to life in prison.

The body of 33-year-old Joshua Lavalley, of Aurora, was found on a snowmobile trail near Hibbing on January 6. Authorities say he had been shot twice in the face.

St. Louis County Judge Mark Starr imposed a life term during Deshon Bonnell's sentencing last week, but also included the possibility of parole after the 19-year-old from Hibbing serves 30 years.

He also was ordered to pay about $6,000 in restitution.

Authorities say there were two alleged accomplices. One of them, Anthony Howson, 21, told police that Lavalley made unwanted sexual contact with Bonnell's girlfriend, Bailey French, 18, according to the Star Tribune.

Howson says Bonnell and French led Lavalley blindfolded into the woods where Bonnell then shot him several times.

Howson told police that he, Bonnell and French had been together with Lavalley that particular January weekend.

Emergency responders went to the Mesabi Trail east of Kerr, after receiving a 911 call from a snowmobiler when they came across Lavalley’s body

Howson and French are also charged in the case. Howson has pleaded guilty to second-degree murder for his role in the killing.

French is charged with first-degree murder and has a hearing scheduled for next month.

She told police that the entire group took Lavalley to where his body 'would later be found.'

Howson claims he stayed in the car while French and Bonnell led a blindfolded Lavalley into the woods. Her boyfriend then shot Lavalley dead.

Bonnell's mother told police that her .22-caliber pistol was missing. A police search of French's home later turned up a .22-caliber pistol under a mattress.
